bestBHT.bht: To speak well of one, to have all men applauding, may seem flattering, but for the disciples of Jesus, it can be a warning. Seeking universal praise and gaining favor from the world may lead to suspicion of unfaithfulness, characterlessness, or the desire to please. As the salt of the earth, disciples should not prioritize the applause of the wicked, but instead focus on preaching sound doctrine and receiving commendation from the righteous.

Henry Alford: The mention of 'prophets' and 'false prophets' has reference to the disciples’ office as the salt of the earth."
The address in ver. 27 is... 'But I say unto you,' which introduces the same command..."
The discourse being in an abridged form, the strong antithesis could not be brought out.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: you—alluding to the court paid to the false prophets of old
of this woe, and its proper limits, see Micah 2:11- :.
John Calvin: Woe to you when all men shall applaud you... the favor of men would prove to be their ruin.
This warning refers peculiarly to teachers, who have no plague more to be dreaded than ambition.
Faithful and conscientious ministers of sound doctrine enjoy the applause and favor of good men.
Philip Schaff: Universal praise from the world is a stigma for the Saviour's disciples, since it brings them into the suspicion of unfaithfulness."
Universal praise from the world is a stigma for the Saviour's disciples, since it brings them into the suspicion of characterlessness."
Universal praise from the world is a stigma for the Saviour's disciples, since it brings them into the suspicion of the lust of pleasing.
Archibald T. Robertson: Praise is sweet to the preacher but all sorts of preachers get it.
To speak one fair, to speak well of one.
John Gill: Woe unto you when all men shall speak well of you!"
It looks ill in persons, when the men of the world, wicked men, all of them, or the greater part of them, applaud and commend them.
For it is no bad sign, to have the good word of good men.
John Wesley: Wo to you when all men shall speak well of you — But who will believe this?

bhtAttempts.bht: Beware when everyone speaks well of you, as it may indicate unfaithfulness or a desire to please rather than a true commitment to the teachings of Christ. This warning specifically applies to disciples of Jesus, who, as the salt of the earth, should not seek universal praise from the world. While it is tempting for preachers to enjoy the sweetness of praise, they must be cautious not to prioritize the favor of men over their duty to preach sound doctrine. Remember, the applause of the wicked is not a commendation to be desired, but the approval of the righteous is a positive sign.

Remember, the applause of the wicked is not a commendation to be desired.

While it is tempting for preachers to enjoy the sweetness of praise, they must be cautious not to prioritize the favor of men over their duty to preach sound doctrine. Remember, the applause of the wicked is not a commendation to be desired.

To speak well of one, to have all men applauding, may seem flattering, but for the disciples of Jesus, it can be a warning. Seeking universal praise and gaining favor from the world may lead to suspicion of unfaithfulness, characterlessness, or the desire to please. As the salt of the earth, disciples should not prioritize the applause of the wicked, but instead focus on preaching sound doctrine and receiving commendation from the righteous.

Beware when everyone speaks well of you, as it may indicate unfaithfulness or a desire to please rather than a true commitment to the teachings of Jesus. This applies specifically to disciples, who should not seek universal praise from the world. Preachers must be cautious not to prioritize the favor of men over their duty to preach sound doctrine. While the applause of the wicked is not desirable, the approval and commendation of the righteous is a positive sign for faithful ministers.
